Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Ken (Stanley),
 
This may sound somewhat Lamarckian (scary).  There seems to be a mechanism
(indicated in recent breast cancer research, for example) that various
exposure to environmental and social conditions does influence genetic
properties.
 
This indicates that there may be "tensor like" ordering/re-ordering effects
(these are my terms, so take them with a grain of salt) on genetic
information.
 
Whether this is effect analogous to mating is unknown (certainly to me), but
the effect needs further investigation both in the natural world and the
artificial one.
 
Ken (Lloyd)


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
kenstanley01
Sent: Wednesday, January 27, 2010 9:36 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Horizontal evolution of evolution


  



I'm trying to understand the algorithmic implications: If I have some good
genetic code that you don't have and give it to you "horizontally," i.e.
without mating, how is that different computationally from me mating with
you and having an offspring that combines all of your code with my bit of
extra code? I guess one difference is that there was no selection operation;
the "offspring" was created without me needing to mate. So it seems like a
sort of less greedy form of selection in which you can pass on your genes
without succeeding at finding a mate or even performing reproduction. Yet is
it anything over and above less greedy evolution? For example, would it be
much different if we just relaxed the criteria of selection? I guess I'm not
sure if the implications are really fundamental or just technical, that is,
if it somehow changes what is possible to discover or if it just means it
happens in a different way than was presumed in some cases.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "R"
<shanemcdonaldryan@...> wrote:
>
> This is an interesting article.
> http://www.newscien
<http://www.newscientist.com/article/mg20527441.500-horizontal-and-vertical-
the-evolution-of-evolution.html?full=true&print=true>
tist.com/article/mg20527441.500-horizontal-and-vertical-the-evolution-of-evo
lution.html?full=true&print=true
> 
> It talks essentially about the process that gave rise to the evolutionary
algorithm and protein synthesis machinery.
> 
> I wonder if you could use something like it to tweak or build an
evolutionary algorithm?
> 
> What do you guys think?
>
